topics.body:
Oi; Thanatos I thought of something related to League.  You know how the reason why league is successful is because it's free to play that offers skins for money?

I've gotten in tera online a bit and what's interesting is that mmorpg games are slowly introducing the same thing.  What is slowly happening is that online rpg games are dumping the pay to win model.

Call me crazy, but personally I think what killed mmorpg popularity was that they started introducing the pay to win model.  If they introduce what league does then chances are they'll make a massive comeback.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/555631716368724dd3d14600#post_555631716368724dd3d14600
I think it will be slitting between a few models based on costs, some games will go the Guild Wars 2 route and be a one time purchase, or take TESO's new approach, others will be able to charge for most of the game and still turn a profit like WoW,
topics.author: 509f70a87f123b77eb0004fd

topics.body:
"@Thanotos Omega":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/555633ca6368724dd3334b00#post_555633ca6368724dd3334b00
Call me crazy, but I think the buying costumes thing is probably the best model because it justifies developing for the game years after it's put out without needing a subscription.

The problem with one time purchase is that without expansion packs the game eventually will be abandoned development wise.

The problem with monthly subscriptions is what happened to WoW in that eventually people stop playing cause they don't want to pay that money.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5556356763687221fa770800#post_5556356763687221fa770800
WoW remains a highly profitable game, Guild Wars 2 has been going strong for several years now, costumes work OK in less RPG focused games Like MOBAs but an actual MMO can sell you lots of things, new areas to explore XP boosts, stuff you can't really sell in a full competitive multi player game,
